isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: PREDICT: untargeted metabolomic profiling in a Brassica napus (canola) breeding population by GC-MS
studies.description: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) identified thousands of genetic loci associated with complex plant traits, including many traits of agronomical importance. However, functional interpretation of GWAS results remains challenging because of large candidate regions due to linkage disequilibrium. High-throughput omics technologies, such as genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics open new avenues for integrative systems biological analyses and help to nominate systems information supported (prime) candidate genes. In the present study, we capitalize on a diverse canola population with spring-type 477 lines which was previously analysed by high-throughput phenotyping (Knoch et al., 2020), and by RNA sequencing and metabolite profiling for multi-omics-based hybrid performance prediction (Knoch et al., 2021). We deepened the phenotypic data analysis, now providing 123 time-resolved image-based traits, to gain insight into the complex relations during early vegetative growth and re-analysed the transcriptome data based on the latest Darmor-bzh v10 genome assembly (Rousseau-Gueutin et al., 2020). Genome-wide association testing revealed 61,298 robust quantitative trait loci (QTL) including 187 metabolite-QTL, 56,814 expression-QTL, and 4,297 phenotypic QTL, many clustered in pronounced hotspots. Combining information about QTL colocalisation across omics layers and correlations between omics features allowed us to discover prime candidate genes for metabolic and vegetative growth variation. Prioritized candidate genes for early biomass accumulation include A06p05760.1_BnaDAR (PIAL1), A10p16280.1_BnaDAR, C07p48260.1_BnaDAR (PRL1), and C07p48510.1_BnaDAR (CLPR4). Moreover, we observed unequal effects of the Brassica A and C subgenomes on early biomass production.

people.address: Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK), 06466 Seeland OT Gatersleben, Germany

publications.title: Multi-omics-based prediction of hybrid performance in canola.
publications.authorList: Knoch D, Werner CR, Meyer RC, Riewe D, Abbadi A, Lücke S, Snowdon RJ, Altmann T.

publications.title: Strong temporal dynamics of QTL action on plant growth progression revealed through high-throughput phenotyping in canola
publications.authorList: Dominic Knoch, Amine Abbadi, Fabian Grandke, Rhonda C. Meyer, Birgit Samans, Christian R. Werner, Rod J. Snowdon, Thomas Altmann

publications.title: Integrated multi-omics analyses and genome-wide association studies reveal prime candidate genes of metabolic and vegetative growth variation in canola.
publications.authorList: Knoch D, Meyer RC, Heuermann MC, Riewe D, Peleke FF, Szymański J, Abbadi A, Snowdon RJ, Altmann T.

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Here, we investigated a genetically diverse population of 477 spring-type canola lines. We re-analysed our previously generated multi-omics data sets[1][2], including image-derived traits (i-traits) based on daily high-throughput phenotyping, gene expression and metabolite profiles from an early vegetative growth stage, and used them to perform extensive genome-wide association studies. Plants were cultivated under controlled environmental conditions in an incomplete randomized block design in 4 experiments[1]. The shoot material from 4 plants per container was collected at 14 days after sowing (DAS), between 7 to 9 h after illumination, and immediately shock-frozen in liquid nitrogen. Plant material was homogenised in a scintillation vial (Zinsser Analytic GmbH, Eschborn, Germany) for 2 min at -60 °C using 2 x 8-mm steel balls and a cryogenic plant grinding and dispensing system (Labman Automation Ltd., Stokesley, United Kingdom). The material of 4 individual plants per carrier was combined and equal amounts of plant material from all carriers from the different experiments were pooled. Samples from the first phenotyping experiment were omitted, as a breakdown of the cooling system in the glasshouse caused elevated temperatures during this experiment and an increased developmental speed, which might have biased the results. 15 ± 1.5 mg fresh weight were dispersed in 1.4 ml storage tubes (Micronic, Lelystad, The Netherlands) for metabolite profiling. For transcript profiling, 50 ± 1.5 mg fresh weight were manually weighed. Material was stored at −80 °C until use.


Ref:

[1] Knoch, D., Abbadi, A., Grandke, F., Meyer, R.C, Samans, B., Werner, C.R., Snowdon, R.J., Altmann, T. 2020. Strong temporal dynamics of QTL action on plant growth progression revealed through high-throughput phenotyping in canola. Plant Biotechnol J 18:68–82. PMID: 31125482. DOI:10.1111/pbi.13171

[2] Knoch, D., Werner, C.R., Meyer, R.C., Riewe, D., Abbadi, A., Lücke, S., Snowdon, R.J., and Altmann, T. 2021. Multi-omics-based prediction of hybrid performance in canola. Theor Appl Genet, 134, 1147–1165. PMID: 33523261. DOI: 10.1007/s00122-020-03759-x

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Metabolite profiling, quality controls and data normalization are as described in associated publication[1]. Polar metabolites were extracted from 15 mg deep-frozen, homogenised plant material using a previously described liquid–liquid extraction protocol[2]-[4]. The protocol was adjusted to 96 tubes/rack format and implemented on a liquid handling system (Biomek FXP, Beckman Coulter GmbH, Krefeld, Germany), 0.625 ml chilled extraction buffer (2.5:1:1 v/v MeOH/CHCl /H2O) and 0.250 ml H2O after incubation. Extraction was split into 6 batches with 96 samples each and aliquots of 50 μl of polar phase were sampled. The dried extracts were in-line chemically derivatized directly, using a two-step methoxyamination (20 mg/mL methoxyamine hydrochloride in pure pyridine)and per-silylation (N-methyl-N-(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide, MSTFA), prior to the GC-MS analysis of the reaction products as previously described[5].


Refs:

[1] Knoch, D., Werner, C.R., Meyer, R.C., Riewe, D., Abbadi, A., Lücke, S., Snowdon, R.J., and Altmann, T. 2021. Multi-omics-based prediction of hybrid performance in canola. Theor Appl Genet, 134, 1147–1165. PMID: 33523261. DOI: 10.1007/s00122-020-03759-x

[2] Riewe D, Koohi M, Lisec J., Pfeiffer, M., Lippmann, R., Schmeichel, J., Willmitzer, L., Altmann, T. 2012. A tyrosine aminotransferase involved in tocopherol synthesis in Arabidopsis. Plant J 71:850– 859. PMID: 22540282. DOI:10.1111/j.1365-313X.2012.05035.x

[3] Riewe, D., Jeon, H.J., Lisec, J., Heuermann, M.C., Schmeichel, J., Seyfarth, M., Meyer, R.C., Willmitzer, L., Altmann, T. 2016. A naturally occurring promoter polymorphism of the Arabidopsis FUM2 gene causes expression variation, and is associated with metabolic and growth traits. Plant J 88:826–838. PMID: 27520391. DOI:10.1111/tpj.13303

[4] Lisec, J., Schauer, N., Kopka, J., Willmitzer, L., Fernie, A.R. 2006. Gas chromatography mass spectrometry-based metabolite profiling in plants. Nat Protoc 1:387–396. PMID: 17406261. DOI:10.1038/nprot.2006.59

[5] Erban, A., Schauer, N., Fernie, A.R., Kopka, J. 2007. Nonsupervised construction and application of mass spectral and retention time index libraries from time-of-fight gas chromatography-mass spectrometry metabolite profiles. Methods Mol Biol 358:19–38. PMID: 17035678. DOI:10.1007/978-1-59745-244-1_2

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description:
In-line derivatization and sample injection was automated using a GERSTEL MultiPurpose Sampler MPS2-XL autosampler. Samples were analyzed in split mode (1:4) using an Agilent 7890A gas chromatography instrument, equipped with a DB-35ms GC Column (0.25 µm, 0.32 mm x 30 m; Agilent Technologies) as previously described[1]-[3]. A sample volume of 1 μl was injected using the auto-sampler at 250 °C with helium carrier gas flow set to 2 ml/min. The flow rate was kept constant with electronic pressure control enabled. Inlet temperature was set to 230 °C. The temperature program of the oven was isothermal for 3 min at 85 °C, followed by a 15 °C per min ramp to 340 °C. Temperature was held at this value for 1.5 min. The transfer line temperature was set to 250 °C.


Refs:

[1] Riewe D, Koohi M, Lisec J., Pfeiffer, M., Lippmann, R., Schmeichel, J., Willmitzer, L., Altmann, T. 2012. A tyrosine aminotransferase involved in tocopherol synthesis in Arabidopsis. Plant J 71:850– 859. PMID: 22540282. DOI:10.1111/j.1365-313X.2012.05035.x

[2] Riewe, D., Jeon, H.J., Lisec, J., Heuermann, M.C., Schmeichel, J., Seyfarth, M., Meyer, R.C., Willmitzer, L., Altmann, T. 2016. A naturally occurring promoter polymorphism of the Arabidopsis FUM2 gene causes expression variation, and is associated with metabolic and growth traits. Plant J 88:826–838. PMID: 27520391. DOI:10.1111/tpj.13303by Riewe et al.

[3] Wiebach, J., Nagel, M., Börner, A., Altmann, T., Riewe, D. 2020. Age-dependent loss of seed viability is associated with increased lipid oxidation and hydrolysis. Plant Cell Environ 43:303–314. PMID: 31472094. DOI:10.1111/ pce.13651

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: The Agilent gas chromatograph was coupled with a LECO Pegasus HT time-of-flight mass spectrometer. The ion source temperature was set to 250 °C. The recorded mass range was 50 to 600 m/z at 20 scans per s. The detector voltage was set to 1,650 V. For ionization 70 eV electrons were used. The instrument was tuned automatically according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
The metabolite intensities were normalized regarding to sample weight and measuring d/detector response. Outliers were removed (median ± 4 x SD), and metabolite data were power transformed to ensure an approximate normal distribution[1].


Ref:

[1] Box, G.E.P., Cox, D.R. 1964. An analysis of transformations. J Roy Stat Soc: Ser B (Methodol) 26:211–252.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
Analyte mass spectra were deconvoluted using the LECO ChromaTOF software including the ‘Statistical Compare’ package. Retention time was converted to Kovats retention indices using 13 fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) standards spiked into each derivatized extract. Chromatographic peaks were annotated by querying the electron impact spectra library provided by the Golm Metabolome Database (GMD), using spectral and retention index matches. Quantitative peak information was extracted with the R package ‘TargetSearch’[1]. Data were filtered for contaminations using a sample to blank ratio > 2. In total, 154 analytes of biological origin, 64 of known and 90 of unknown chemical structure, were quantified.


Ref:

[1] Cuadros-Inostroza, A., Caldana, C., Redestig, H., Kusano, M., Lisec, J., Peña-Cortés, H., Willmitzer, L., Hannah, M.A. 2009. TargetSearch– a Bioconductor package for the efcient preprocessing of GC-MS metabolite profling data. BMC Bioinform 10:428. PMID: 20015393. DOI:10.1186/1471-2105-10-428
